sponsoredBills: An Act to improve the Commonwealth’s economy with a strong minimum wage and a strong tipped minimum wage
Raises minimum wage to $15 by 2021 and indexes it to inflation. Ensures that tipped employees’ wages plus tips equal the new strengthened minimum wage.
An Act to improve the Commonwealth’s economy with a strong minimum wage and a strong tipped minimum wage
Raises minimum wage to $15 by 2021 and indexes it to inflation. Ensures that tipped employees’ wages plus tips equal the new strengthened minimum wage.
An Act establishing a paid family and medical leave insurance program
Makes employees eligible for job-protected paid leave to recover from a serious illness or injury, to care for a seriously ill or injured family member, or to care for a new child.
An Act establishing a paid family and medical leave insurance program
Makes employees eligible for job-protected paid leave to recover from a serious illness or injury, to care for a seriously ill or injured family member, or to care for a new child.
An Act promoting housing and sustainable development
Upgrades state’s zoning laws to encourage more affordable housing and transit-oriented, walkable development, and promotes inclusionary zoning  practices.
An Act establishing Medicare for All in Massachusetts
Establishes a single payer system, in which the state provides health care to all residents as a right.
An Act establishing Medicare for All in Massachusetts
Establishes a single payer system, in which the state provides health care to all residents as a right.
An Act modernizing the Foundation Budget for the 21st century
Robust and equitable K-12 public ed funding
Requires the state to implement the recommendations of the the 2015 Foundation Budget Review Commission on K-12 education.
An Act making public higher education in Massachusetts free for residents of the state
Establishes free college tuition and fees for all Massachusetts residents.
An Act promoting access to debt-free public higher education
Establishes free college (community college and/or state university) education for students of all families earning $200,000 a year or less, covering tuition, fees, housing, and transportation costs.
Justice reform & reinvestment (or "jobs and education, not jails and incarceration")
Enacts comprehensive justice reform, complementing reductions in sentencing with jobs training, youth jobs, and pre-apprenticeship programs.
Justice reform & reinvestment (or "jobs and education, not jails and incarceration")
Enacts comprehensive justice reform, complementing reductions in sentencing with jobs training, youth jobs, and pre-apprenticeship programs.
An Act to eliminate mandatory minimum sentences related to drug offenses
Restores judicial discretion in sentencing for nonviolent drug charges, reducing the economic and social costs of extended prison terms.
An Act to eliminate mandatory minimum sentences related to drug offenses
Restores judicial discretion in sentencing for nonviolent drug charges, reducing the economic and social costs of extended prison terms.
An Act to protect the civil rights and safety of all Massachusetts residents (“Safe Communities Act”)

Prohibits the use of state resources for mass deportations or deportation raids, limits local and state police collaboration with federal immigration agents, and prohibits state support for Muslim registry.
An Act to protect the civil rights and safety of all Massachusetts residents (“Safe Communities Act”)

Prohibits the use of state resources for mass deportations or deportation raids, limits local and state police collaboration with federal immigration agents, and prohibits state support for Muslim registry.
An Act to reduce the criminalization of poverty
Eliminates or reduces numerous fees, such as parole supervision, and ensures indigent residents are not jailed or given unreasonable fees simply because they struggle to pay court-related fines.
An Act to reduce the criminalization of poverty
Eliminates or reduces numerous fees, such as parole supervision, and ensures indigent residents are not jailed or given unreasonable fees simply because they struggle to pay court-related fines.
An Act relative to advancing contraceptive coverage and economic security in our state (ACCESS)
Updates MA’s contraceptive coverage equity law to require insurance carriers to provide all contraceptive methods without a copay.
An Act relative to advancing contraceptive coverage and economic security in our state (ACCESS)
Updates MA’s contraceptive coverage equity law to require insurance carriers to provide all contraceptive methods without a copay.
An Act automatically registering eligible voters and enhancing safeguards against fraud

Modernizes voter registration by automatically registering citizens who interact with government agencies ("opt-out" instead of "opt-in") and ensures that such information is handled in a secure fashion.
An Act automatically registering eligible voters and enhancing safeguards against fraud

Modernizes voter registration by automatically registering citizens who interact with government agencies ("opt-out" instead of "opt-in") and ensures that such information is handled in a secure fashion.
An Act creating 21st Century Massachusetts clean energy jobs

Establishes a climate adaptation and management program, sets greenhouse gas reduction targets for 2030 and 2040, accelerates the state’s Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS), and increases commitment to offshore wind.
An Act relative to solar power and the green economy
Accelerates the state’s commitment to clean energy (RPS increase) and sets 25% by 2030 solar target.
An Act relative to solar power and the green economy
Accelerates the state’s commitment to clean energy (RPS increase) and sets 25% by 2030 solar target.
An Act clarifying authorities and responsibilities of the Department of Public Utilities
Holds gas companies to a high standard with regards to new infrastructure and prevents massive public subsidy of new interstate gas pipelines.
An Act clarifying authorities and responsibilities of the Department of Public Utilities
Holds gas companies to a high standard with regards to new infrastructure and prevents massive public subsidy of new interstate gas pipelines.
An Act to promote green infrastructure, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and create jobs
Enacts revenue-positive carbon pricing. 80% is rebated to residents while 20% is invested in green infrastructure, with a carve-out for low-income communities.
Enacts revenue-neutral carbon pricing. Every state resident receives an equal rebate, and employers get rebates based on their number of employees.
houseBills:
190.1h - Good Government

Vote was on giving pay increases to the Senate President, Speaker of the House, judges, the governor, and other constitutional officers; raising stipends to appointed committee chairs and select other legislative leaders; and increasing the number of legislators eligible for stipends. The bill would further centralize power in the already powerful House Speaker and create a more hierarchical and less democratic Legislature. The bill received little notice and no public hearing, and was fast-tracked while many vital priorities to the Commonwealth languish in perpetuity.

(Roll Call #5, H58, 1/25/2017. Progressive Position: No)

.
An Act Further Regulating the Compensation of Public Officials

190.2h - Good Govt, Transparency 

Vote was on requiring committee roll call votes to be posted on the Clerks’ websites. This is current practice in the Senate, but not the House. 

(Roll Call #19, Bill H2019, Amdt 11, 2/2/2017, Progressive Position: Yes)

.

190.3h – Revenue, Taxation  

Vote was on reducing the state income tax to 5.0% (from its current 5.1%) by the effective date of 2016’s Question 4 to further study,
thereby draining the state of much-needed revenue. 

(Roll Call #26, Bill H3600, Amdt 861, 4/24/2017, Progressive Position: NO)

.

1890.h - Revenue, Taxation 

Vote was on sending an amendment to reduce the sales tax from 6.25% to 5.00% to further study, thereby dispensing with it. The amendment would have drained the state of much-needed revenue.

(Roll Call #30, Bill H3600, Amdt 815.1, 4/24/2017, Progressive Position: Yes)
.
Further to An Amendment to Restore the 5% Sales Tax

190.5h - Housing, Immigration

Vote was on dispensing with an amendment that would prevent mixed-status immigrant families from living in public housing. 

(Roll Call #41, Bill H3600, Amdt 971.1, 4/25/2017; Progressive Position: Yes)

.

190.6h - Welfare, Poverty

Vote was on sending to further study an amendment that would deny cash benefits to individuals who use such benefits in non-bordering states, thereby dispensing with it. 

(Roll Call #43, Bill H3600,Amendment 966.1, 4/25/2017, Progressive Position: Yes)

.
Further Amendment to Cash Assistance Expenditures

190.10h: Revenue, Taxation, Education, Transportation

Vote was on sending the Fair Share amendment, which would impose a 4% surtax on income above $1 million and allocate the revenue to a designated education and transportation fund, to the 2018 ballot.  

(Roll Call #67, Bill S10, 6/14/2017; Progressive Position: Yes)

.

190.7h - Criminal Justice, Health, Drug War

Vote was on amending the House's marijuana regulation bill to prevent cities and towns that pass local bans on marijuana from receiving substance treatment and prevention funds from the bill, creating an incentive to prevent the concentration of marijuana stores in urban areas alone.

(Roll Call #69, Bill H3768, Amendment Consolidated B, 6/2/2017, Progressive Position: Yes)

.
Funds Directed only to Participating Communities
Criminal Justice, Racial Equity, Gender Equity, Drug War

190.8h - Criminal Justice, Racial Equity, Gender Equity, Drug War

Vote was on promoting the inclusion of women- and minority-owned businesses in the cannabis industry, encouraging the full participation of communities that had been disproportionately harmed by the war on drugs, sealing marijuana offenses that are no longer considered a crime, and other steps toward racial equity. 

(Roll Call #70, Bill H3768, Consolidated B, 6/2/2017, Progressive Position: Yes)

.
Criminal Justice, Racial Equity, Gender Equity, Drug War

190.9h Criminal Justice, Drug War 

Vote was on significantly rewriting the language on marijuana legalization passed via Question 4 on the 2016 ballot. The bill would more than double the tax on marijuana, creating the conditions for black market to flourish; eliminate the ability of voters to have a direct say over local marijuana policy; and create new law enforcement agencies with broad and poorly defined powers -- while weakening core equity provisions. 

(Roll Call #72, Bill H3768, 6/2/2017 Progressive Position: No)

.

An Act to ensure the public health and safety of patient and consumer 
access to medical and adult use of marijuana in the Commonwealth

190.11h - Criminal Justice, Drug War

Vote was on the conference committee version of the Question 4 redraft (marijuana legalization), which remained faithful to the spirit of the original ballot
initiative, while containing improvements in public health and social justice.

(Roll Call #77, Bill 3818, 7/19/2017, Progressive Position: Yes)

.
An act to ensure safe access to marijuana

190.12h - Health Care

Vote was on freezing employer contributions to the unemployment insurance trust fund, a $334 million giveaway that depletes an already underfunded program (proposed in an attempt to sweeten a tax on employers whose workers get coverage from MassHealth). 

(Roll Call #78, Bill H3822, Amendment 2, 7/26/2017, Progressive Position: No)

.

190.13h - Health Care

Vote was on Governor Baker’s proposal to drop 100,000 low-income parents and 40,000 other adults off MassHealth, a proposal which would subject such individuals to higher premiums and a loss of dental coverage and other vital benefits.

(Roll Call #79, Bill H3822, 7/26/2017, Progressive Position: No)

.
An Act Further Regulating Employer Contributions to Health Care

190.14h - Climate Change, Environmental Protection 

Vote was on committing Massachusetts to the greenhouse gas emissions reduction goals laid out in the Paris Climate Agreement. The bill would make Massachusetts a “non-party stakeholder” to the agreement and allow state officials to document their emissions reductions efforts through a UN-developed online data-gathering tool.


(Roll Call #276, Bill H3994, 11/1/2017, Progressive Position: Yes)

.
An Act relative to Massachusetts participation in the Paris Climate Agreement's Green House Gas Emission Standards

190.15 - Reproductive Rights, Health Care

Vote was on updating MA’s contraceptive coverage equity law to require insurance carriers to provide all contraceptive methods without a copay.

(Roll Call #279, Bill H4099, 11/8/2017, Progressive Position: Yes)
An Act relative to advancing contraceptive coverage and economic security in our state (ACCESS)

190.17h - Immigration, Policing 

Vote was on upholding the ruling of the Chair that an amendment to give local law enforcement authority to hold people in custody based on a detainer from ICE was out of order. The amendment would have violated the constitutional rights of the immigrants being held.

(Roll Call #285, Bill H4011, Chair's Ruling on Amendment 27, 11/13/2017, Progressive Position: YES)
.
Detention Request -- Upholding the Ruling of the Chair

190.18h - Criminal Justice Reform, Drug War 

Vote was on sending to further study (i.e., dispensing with) an amendment to manslaughter charges for anyone providing a drug that results in death, which would have made such individuals less likely to call for emergency medical help in such situations.

(Roll Call #286, Bill H4011, Further Amendment to Amendment 23, 11/14/2017, Progressive Position: YES )
.
Further amdt to Penalty or heroin trafficking resulting in death

190.19h - Surveillance

Vote was on upholding the ruling of the Chair that the amendment to expand the state’s wiretapping law and curtail privacy rights was out of order. 

(Roll Call #287, Bill H4011, Point of order on Amendment 53, 11/14/2017. Progressive Position: YES)

190.20h - Criminal Justice Reform, Juvenile Justice 

Vote was on allowing for the expungement of certain juvenile records after 7 years in the case of a felony and after 3 years in the case of a misdemeanor, enabling people to have second chance and better reintegrate into the community. 

(Roll Call #290, Bill H4011, Amdt 160, 11/14/2017. Progressive Position: YES)
.

190.21h - Criminal Justice Reform

Vote was on raising the threshold at which larceny (theft) is treated as a felony, rather than a misdemeanor, from $250 to $1,000. The current felony-larceny threshold in Massachusetts is the third lowest in the country. 

(Roll Call #291, Bill H4011, Amendment 3, 11/14/2017, Progressive Position: YES)

190.22h - Criminal Justice Reform

Vote was on expanding the witness intimidation statute to cover more people and transactions and have higher penalties, opening up possibilities for police and prosecutorial abuse given the lack of requirement for an empirical foundation for such charges.

(Roll Call #292, Bill H4011, Amendment 54, 11/14/2017, Progressive Position: NO)

190.23h - Criminal Justice Reform

Vote was on raising the felony threshold for malicious destruction of property from property valued over $250 to damage valued over $1,000 and changes the fine calculating factor from $3000 or three times the value of the property to $3000 or three times the value of the damage caused to the property

(Roll Call #294, Bill H4011, Amendment 80, 11/14/2017, Progressive Position: YES)

190.24h - Criminal Justice Reform, Drug War

Vote was on sending to further study (i.e., dispensing with) an amendment to manslaughter charges for anyone providing a drug that results in death, which would have made such individuals less likely to call for emergency medical help in such situations. 

(Roll Call #295, Bill H4011, Further Amendment to Amendment 121, 11/14/2017, Progressive Position: YES )
Further amdt to Drug Distribution Causing Death

190.24h - Criminal Justice Reform

Vote was on passing the conference committee criminal justice reform bill that, while imperfect, took significant steps toward curbing mass incarceration in Massachusetts 

(Roll Call #320, Bill S2371, 4/4/2018, Progressive Position: YES )
An Act Relative to Criminal Justice Reform

190.25h - Immigration, policing

Vote was on a budget amendment to allow state and local law enforcement agencies to arrest and hold without a warrant a person suspected of immigration violations, which would violate basic constitutional rights and make communities less safe. 

(Roll Call #334, Bill H4400, Amendment 347, 4/25/2018, Progressive Position: NO )

190.26h Immigration, Policing, Local aid 

Vote was to table ("send to further study)" an amendment to block local aid to communities that have adopted ordinances or policies restricting local police from cooperating with federal ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement) agents.

(Roll Call #335, Bill H4400, Amendment 347, 4/25/2018, Progressive Position: YES)
Tabling an amendment to block local aid to sanctuary cities

190.27h Corporate Tax Giveaways

Vote was on reauthorizing a corporate tax giveaway for the biotech industry, including provisions increasing the amount  of money available each year for industry tax incentives and thus draining much-needed revenue.

(Roll Call #349, Bill H4501, 5/16/2018, Progressive Position: NO)
An act providing continued investment in the life sciences industry
Gun Violence, Public Safety, Public Health

190.28h Gun Violence, Public Safety, Public Health

Vote was on amending the Extreme Risk Protection Order (ERPO) bill to require the state to provide a mental health assessment of an individual who receives an ERPO within 48 hours and, if deemed necessary, to create a mental health program for that individual. The amendment aimed to stigmatize mental illness and evade the root issue of gun violence.

(Roll Call #352, Bill H4517, Amendment 6, 5/23/2018, Progressive Position: NO)
Gun Violence, Public Safety, Public Health
Gun Violence, Public Safety, Public Health

190.29h Gun Violence, Public Safety, Public Health

Vote was on amending the ERPO (Extreme Risk Protection Order) bill to increase the evidentiary standard for approving an ERPO from “the preponderance of evidence” to “clear and convincing evidence," an attempt to nullify the bill’s ability to prevent mass shootings or suicides.

(Roll Call #356, Bill H4517, 5/23/2018, Progressive Position: NO)
Increasing the standard to ‘clear and convincing evidence’ for the Courts to approve an ERPO petition
Gun Violence, Public Safety, Public Health
Gun Violence, Public Safety, Public Health

190.30h Gun Violence, Public Safety, Public Health

Vote was on creating a kind of court order (Extreme Risk Protection Order, or ERPO) to temporarily restrict a person's access to guns because they pose a significant danger to themselves or others, which can be requested by family members and law enforcement. Empowering family members, who are able to see early warning signs, to act in this way can prevent gun violence, whether mass shooting or suicide.

(Roll Call #359, Bill H4517, 5/23/2018, Progressive Position: YES)
Gun Violence, Public Safety, Public Health

190.32h Health Care, Consumer Protection

Vote was on amending the House’s health care reform bill to require surgeons intending to operate on multiple patients at once to seek informed consent of the patients. Recent studies have shown that double-booked surgeries put patients at extra risks.

(Roll Call #374, Bill H4617, Amendment 1, 6/19/2018, Progressive Position: YES)

190.33h Economic Rights, Labor, Taxation


Vote was on moving forward the “Grand Bargain” deal on the $15 minimum wage, paid family and medical leave, and sales tax holiday ballot initiatives before the Raise Up Massachusetts coalition, the grassroots coalition of community, faith, and labor groups and leaders behind the ballot campaigns for a $15 minimum wage and paid family and medical leave, had the opportunity to review the package and make recommendations. The "Grand Bargain" weakened the $15 minimum wage and paid leave proposals, and authorized the elimination of time-and-a-half on Sundays. 

(Roll Call #377, Bill H4640, 6/20/2018, Progressive Position: NO)
Preventing activists from weighing in on the "Grand Bargain" deal

190.34h LGBTQ Rights

Vote was on amending the underlying bill to allow for the abusive practice of “conversion therapy” via “talk therapy” aimed at coercing a change in an individual’s sexual orientation or gender identity.

(Roll Call #383, Bill H4664, 6/27/2018, Progressive Position: NO)
Homophobia under the Guise of Free Speech

190.35h LGBTQ Rights

Vote was on prohibiting licensed mental health professionals from “practicing” on minors the damaging and homophobic/transphobic fraud of “conversion therapy,” which has the goal of “changing” a person’s sexual orientation or gender identity of a minor.

(Roll Call #384, Bill H4664, 6/27/2018, Progressive Position: YES)
An Act relative to abusive practices to change sexual orientation and gender identity in minors (Conversion Therapy Ban)

190.36h Voting Rights, Democracy

Vote was on adopting Automatic Voter Registration, in which eligible voters who interface with the RMV or MassHealth would be automatically registered to vote unless they decline. With more than 700,000 eligible citizens in MA unregistered, AVR would increase the accuracy, security, and comprehensiveness of voter rolls.

(Roll Call #387, Bill H4667, 6/27/2018, Progressive Position: YES)
An Act automatically registering voters and enhancing safeguards against fraud (AVR)

190.37h Taxation, Revenue

Vote was on creating a sales tax holiday in August 2018. Sales tax holidays are gimmicks that drain the state of much-needed revenue and do  not succeed at meaningfully boosting sales for small businesses.

(Roll Call #392, Bill H4714, 7/10/2018, Progressive Position: NO)

190.38h Health Care, Civil Liberties

Vote was on sending to further study (i.e., tabling) an amendment to reinsert language giving physicians and other clinical professionals the  power to involuntarily hold, for 72 hours, individuals suffering from addiction. People who undergo involuntary treatment in Massachusetts are  twice as likely to die as people who undergo treatment voluntarily.

(Roll Call #398, Bill H4725, 7/11/2018, Progressive Position: YES)

190.39h Immigration, Policing, Civil Rights

Vote was on accepting the conference report version of the 2019 budget, which had stripped out vital protections for immigrant families (as found in Safe Communities Act (SCA))
which had been passed by the MA Senate. Failure to include these SCA provisions in the budget was effectively the last opportunity for the MA Legislature to advance meaningful reforms and protections for immigrants in MA, who are under increasing threat from the Trump Administration’s baldly racist agenda.

(Roll Call #408, Bill H4800, 7/18/2018, Progressive Position: NO)
On Acceptance of the Conference Report (FY 2019 Budget, without SCA provisions)

190.40h Reproductive Rights

Vote was on repealing outdated and unconstitutional laws still on the books limiting reproductive rights. As the possibility of Roe v. Wade deterioration increases with each Trump Supreme Court appointee, it is more important than ever that state legislatures lead in protecting and advancing women’s reproductive rights.

(Roll Call #409, Bill S2260, 7/18/2018, Progressive Position: YES)
An Act negating archaic statutes targeting young women (NASTY Women Act)

190.42h Labor, Economic Rights, Education

Vote was on overriding Republican Governor Charlie Baker’s veto of a bill requiring that the hiring, promotion and termination of employees in custodial, maintenance and other non-teaching positions in public schools be conducted in accordance with any governing collective bargaining agreement. Weakening unions is an important piece of our alarming, and growing, wealth and income inequality.

(Roll Call #451, Bill H1390, 7/27/2018, Progressive Position: YES)
Override: An Act Relative to protecting the rights of custodial and other non-teaching employees of school districts

190.43h Housing, Taxation

Vote was on creating a tax and regulatory framework for short-term rentals like Airbnb, which have exacerbated the affordable housing crisis by taking units off the market and turning them into investment properties.

(Roll Call #452, Bill H4841, 7/30/2018, Progressive Position: YES)
An Act regulating and insuring short-term rentals (Conference Report)

190.44h Poverty, Economic Rights

Vote was to override Republican Governor Baker’s veto of language that would prevent his administration from effectively denying vulnerable children needed welfare benefits, by unilaterally counting a parent’s Social Security Income (afforded to disabled adults who are low-income) to determine children’s benefits eligibility. 

(Roll Call #458, Bill H4800, 7/30/2018, Progressive Position: YES)

190.45h Poverty, Economic Rights

Vote was on a proposal from Republican Governor Charlie Baker to make the adoption of a more stringent calculation of benefits (counting a parent's Supplemental Security Income in determining their children's eligibility for welfare benefits) a precondition of lifting the punitive "cap on kids." Massachusetts is one of the only states that still denies benefits to children who were born while a family is receiving state assistance, and Baker's proposal sought to weaken the Legislature's effort to fix this. 

(Roll Call #480, Bill H4823 7/30/2018, Progressive Position: NO)
Baker's punitive attack on low-income families
senateBills:
190.1s: Good Govt; Leadership

Vote was on giving pay increases to the Senate President, Speaker of the House, judges, the governor, and other constitutional officers; raising stipends to appointed committee chairs and select other legislative leaders; and increasing the number of legislators eligible for stipends. The bill would further centralize power in the already powerful House Speaker and create a more hierarchical and less democratic Legislature. The bill received little notice and no public hearing, and was fast-tracked while many vital priorities to the Commonwealth languish in perpetuity.

(PM Score 190.1s: Roll Call #2, Bill H.58, A1/26/2017, Progressive Position: NO)
An Act Further Regulating the Compensation of Public Officials

190.2s: Environment

Vote was on increasing the FY 2018 administrative budget of the Department of Environmental Protection by $1 million, from $25 million to $26 million (One of PM's budget asks).
 
(PM Score 190.2s: Roll Call #33, Bill S.3, Amdt. 790, 5/25/2017, Progressive Position: YES)

190.3s: Justice

Vote was on increasing the FY 2018 budget of the Massachusetts Legal Assistance Corporation, which provides access to legal information, advice, and representation, for low-income MA residents by $2 million, from $18 million to $20 million (One of PM’s budget asks). 

(PM Score 190.3s: Roll Call #36, Bill S.3, Amdt. 896, 5/25/2017, Progressive Position: YES)

190.4s: Public Education 

Vote was on establishing a schedule for implementing the 2015 recommendations of the Foundation Budget Review Commission. The FBRC found that the Commonwealth is underestimating the cost of K-12 education by $1-2 billion each year due to outdated assumptions regarding the costs of special education and closing the achievement gaps for low-income students and English Language Learners. (One of PM’s budget asks)

(PM Score 190.4s: Roll Call #40, Bill S.3, Amdt. 75, 5/25/2017, Progressive Position: YES)

190.5s: Public Education 

Vote was on eliminating the use of student standardized test performance in teacher evaluations. The use of student impact ratings in teacher evaluation ignores the many other factors, both individual and social, that affect a student’s performance, and creates problems in subjects where standardized tests are not given, such as in art, music, and gym.

(PM Score 190.5s: Roll Call #41, Bill S.3, Amdt. 99, 5/25/2017, Progressive Position: YES)
Improving Overall Student Performance and Opportunity (Redraft)

190.6s: Revenue, Taxation, Education, Transportation

Vote was on sending the Fair Share amendment, which would impose a 4% surtax on income above $1 million and allocate the revenue to a designated education and transportation fund, to the 2018 ballot.

(PM Score 190.6s: Roll Call #47, Bill S.10, 6/14/2017, Progressive Position: YES)

190.7s: Criminal Justice, Health, Drug War

Vote was on revising the language of Question 4 (marijuana legalization) while remaining faithful to its spirit. The bill contains language to promote economic opportunities in communities hurt by the drug war and to expunge the records of those convicted of offenses no longer deemed criminal, along with various further equity, educational, and environmental measures.

(PM Score 190.7s: Roll Call #52, Bill S.2090, Amdt. , 6/22/2017, Progressive Position: YES)
An Act to Ensure the Public Health and Safety of Patient and Consumer Access to Medical and Adult Use of Marijuana in the Commonwealth

190.8s: Criminal Justice

The vote was on reducing the fine scale in the underlying bill, which created penalties for individuals who use their phones while driving, from $100-$250-$500 to $50-$100-$150. 

(PM Score 190.8s: Roll Call #54, Bill S.2092, Amdt. 7, 6/29/2017, Progressive Position: YES)

190.9s: Criminal Justice, Health, Drug War

Vote was on the conference committee version of the Question 4 redraft (marijuana legalization), which remained faithful to the spirit of the original ballot initiative, while containing improvements in public health and social justice.

(PM Score 190.9s: Roll Call #60, Bill H.3818, 7/19/2017, Progressive Position: YES)
An Act to Ensure Safe Access to Marijuana
Health, LGBTQ, Public Education, Reproductive Rights

190.10s: Health, LGBTQ, Public Education, Reproductive Rights

Vote was on requiring that sex education only be offered in schools on an elective basis, with written parent/guardian permission required for student participation

(PM Score 190.10s: Roll Call #62, Bill S.2113, Amdt. 4, 7/20/2017, Progressive Position: NO)
Opt In (An Act Relative to Health Youth)
Health, LGBTQ, Public Education, Reproductive Rights

190.11s: Health, LGBTQ, Public Education, Reproductive Rights

Vote was on ensuring that a Massachusetts school electing to teach sex education uses a medically accurate, age-appropriate, and comprehensive curriculum. This would entail teaching students about the benefits of abstinence and delaying sex, building healthy relationships, consent, gender identity and sexual orientation, effective contraceptive use, and the prevention of pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections (STIs).

(PM Score 190.11s: Roll Call #66, Bill S.2113, 7/20/2017, Progressive Position: YES)
An Act Relative to Health Youth

190.12s: Health Care

Vote was on rejecting Governor Baker’s proposal to drop 100,000 low-income parents and 40,000 other adults off MassHealth, a proposal which would subject such individuals to higher premiums and a loss of dental coverage and other vital benefits.

(PM Score 190.12s: Roll Call #68, Bill H.3822, Amdt. Governor's Amdt, 7/26/2017, Progressive Position: YES)
An Act Furter Regulating Employer Contributions to Health Care

190.13s: Criminal Justice Reform

Vote was on lowering the felony larceny threshold in the bill from $1,500 to $1,000. 


(PM Score 190.13s: Roll Call #205, Bill S.2185, Amdt. 5, 10/26/2017, Progressive Position: NO)

190.14s: Criminal Justice Reform

Vote was on raising the fines in the bill associated with drunk driving, contradicting the bill's goal of reducing fees and fines. 
 
(PM Score 190.14s: Roll Call #206, Bill S.2185, Amdt. 12, 10/26/2017, Progressive Position: NO)
Increased Penalties for Habitual Drunk Drivers

190.15s: Criminal Justice Reform

Vote was on establishing a new mandatory minimum for the crime of assaulting a police officer, which could have a chilling effect on protesters, especially ones of color.

(PM Score 190.15s: Roll Call #211, Bill S.2185, Amdt. 39, 10/26/2017, Progressive Position: NO)
Assault and Battery on a Police Officer

190.16s: Criminal Justice Reform, Civil Rights

Vote was on establishing a new mandatory minimum for the crime of assaulting a police officer, which could have a chilling effect on protesters, especially ones of color. [Some members asked for a 2nd opportunity to vote]

(PM Score 190.16s: Roll Call #214, Bill S.2185, Amdt. 39, 10/26/2017, Progressive Position: NO)
Assault and Battery on a Police Officer

190.17s: Criminal Justice Reform, Civil Rights

Vote was on allowing current prisoners serving mandatory minimum sentences for crimes for which mandatory minimums have been repealed to be eligible for good conduct credits earned on and after the effective date of the law.

(PM Score 190.17s: Roll Call #212, Bill S.2185, Amdt. 149, 10/26/2017, Progressive Position: YES)

190.18s: Criminal Justice Reform, Juvenile Justice

Vote was on recriminalizing the act of disturbing a school assembly. The underlying bill established that it would no longer be an arrestable offense, allowing schools to handle discipline and seeking to curb the school-to-prison pipeline. 

(PM Score 190.18s: Roll Call #213, Bill S.2185, Amdt. 58, 10/26/2017, Progressive Position: NO)

190.19s: Criminal Justice Reform, Drug War

Vote was on reimposing mandatory minimums for low-level cocaine offenses, entrenching the failed model of the war on drugs which has played a significant role in mass incarceration.

(PM Score 190.19s: Roll Call #215, Bill S.2185, Amdt. 60, 10/26/2017, Progressive Position: NO)

190.20s: Criminal Justice Reform, Drug War

Vote was on reimposing mandatory minimums for low-level cocaine offenses, entrenching the failed model of the war on drugs which has played a significant role in mass incarceration.

(PM Score 190.20s: Roll Call #217, Bill S.2185, Amdt. 121, 10/26/2017, Progressive Position: NO)

190.21s: Criminal Justice Reform, Drug War

190.24s: Criminal Justice Reform, Juvenile Justice
